title-group.article-title: Cold Pumpability Characteristics of Engine Oils Predicted by a Bench Test

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc. 1975

abstract.p: The cold pumpability characteristics of nine commercial crankcase oils were evaluated using a V-8 engine and a bench test. These nine oils included most of the SAE viscosity classifications. The engine data were used for evaluating the ability of the bench test to predict the cold pumpability properties of crankcase oils. Additional tests were conducted to study some unusual cold pumping properties of two of the oils. One of these oils was very soak-time sensitive, while the other was found to improve in pumpability after only brief use in the test engine.

ref.mixed-citation: Letter from Wildrick Hart, chairman of SAE Fuels and Lubricants Technical Committee, Subcommittee 2 on Engine Oils, to W. A. Wright, chairman ASTM R&D Division VII of Committee D-2 on Petroleum Products and Lubricants, Feb. 5, 1971.
Letter from R. M. Stewart, subsection chairman of ASTM R&D Division VII B-3 to members of the subsection, Sept. 6, 1973.

R. M. Stewart and M. F. Smith, Jr., "Proposed Labora- tory Methods for Predicting the Low Temperature Pumpa- bility Properties of Crankcase Oils." Published in SP-382, "Viscometry and its Application to Automotive Lubricants." New York: Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1973, paper 730479.

M. F. Smith, Jr. and J. P. Graham, "Pumpability of Multigrade Engine Oils at Low Temperature." SAE Transac- tions, Vol. 80 (1971), paper 710139.
